summary: In the village of Ramgarh, retired police chief Thakur Baldev Singh (Sanjeev Kumar) plots to bring down the notorious bandit Gabbar Singh (Amjad Khan) and enlists the help of two lesser criminals, Jai (Amitabh Bachchan) and Veeru (Dharmendra). When Gabbar attacks the village, however, Jai and Veeru wonder why Thakur does nothing to help them. They soon learn that he has no arms, and that Gabbar was the one who cut them off. Enraged by this, they redouble their efforts to help.

reviews.content: You will never feel tired of watching this masterpiece an 100th time.
Watch it before you die

Arresting, colorful visuals and an amazing score coupled with an interesting western-inspired narrative made Sholay a true gem of Indian cinema. This is a great example of what Bollywood does best – mixing the various different genres and tones into one mostly coherent movie. The western core is also imbued with wonderful action-adventure elements and some truly fantastic songs, which are surprising scene-stealers. The characters are endearing, the villain is menacing and the central male friendship is wonderful. It's uneven in some sections, but for the most part this is a genuine classic and a reminder of how epic cinema truly was in the past.
A groundbreaking movie. In a lot ways evolved Bollywood industry. Amitabh's role wasn't main but still it became memorable.

The most iconic movie of Indian cinema in the 70's. I dunno what a non Indian watching it today would think but nostalgia for us old school peeps.
https://m.timesofindia.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/photo-features/sholay40-iconic-dialogue-from-the-film/sholay40-iconic-dialogue-from-the-film/photostory/48482660.cms

I only recently learned about the movie and it did not disappoint! It watched like an old Western movie my dad would have watched with me but with the unique local flare of its origin country. Definitely take the time to give it a watch!

"Sholay" is widely considered one of the most successful Bollywood films ever made, and after finally getting around to watching it, it's easy to see why. This movie delivers a lot of solid entertainment with its fun characters and fast-paced action scenes. The movie has a lot more humor than I anticipated and the movie has a great villain that is entertaining but also menacing when he needs to be. The premise of this movie feels very old school similar to a classic Western in Hollywood but I actually liked this movie more than the iconic Westerns I have seen so far. This movie is a bit silly and over the top, but it is easy to overlook because of how often it is fun to watch. I did feel the movie was a bit long and sometimes the pacing is affected because of it. However, as a whole package, I think the movie is a lot of fun and one that I can see how it has gone down to be a well-known classic for many people.
If you like westerns like The Good, The Bad and The Ugly and 3-hour epics like The Godfather then Sholay is an incredible movie. I think it's safe to say most Indians have seen this masterpiece!
FRIENDSHIP 1st , Revenge 2nd........ Add something to the 3D graphics too!   Arrival of modern action direction.
Greatest hindi movie ever made

This movie is a mixture of everything, romance, drama, thrill, action, an overall package. The 3+ hours long runtime gets a little exhausting at times but overall it's worth a five star rating. Not to forget this movie was made at the time when dramas and love stories were supposed to be the only plotline of an average Bollywood movie. Amazing writing, stunning performances, great direction. Evergreen.
Amazing movie, one of the greatest movies of all time!

Sholay is one of India's biggest cinematic achievements.This is one film that retells a simple story of adventure and revenge.But where it becomes legendary is when it uses colourful characters with motivations and meaning to the plot carefully while also not making any person feels the tiresome three hour plot structure.This is one of those cinematic gems which can never be replicated.
Full on entertainment and drama and the man saying "Kitne aadmi the"... go ahead and experience it instead of reading about the movie any further.
A true classic--an inspiration for many films that followed.
India's Seven Samurai but with only two.

If you liked "Once upon a time in the west", "The magnificent seven" and "A fistful of dollars", you will love "Sholay". It takes all the good ingredients of a western, spices it with a lot of Indian ingredients and lets it simmer until you get one of the finest "curry" westerns imaginable. Though obviously very much inspired by the "spaghetti" westerns of the late 1960s/early 1970s, this easily surpasses most of the films it's modeled after. A masterpiece.

One of the most iconic movie of all time. A movie of epic proportions with heavyweight actors such as the big bacchan and Sanjeev kumar and dharamendra and Hema Malini but one man who stole the limelight was Amjad Khan
one of my favorite bollywood pix
a wonderful story of love and friendship!
Greatest hindi movie of all time

Hey, it's a rip-roaring good time, as two criminals help a former police officer in his (extremely personal) battle with a gang of bandits, led by a particularly evil guy.  This is Bollywood, so characters spontaneously break out in song and/or dance (or are forced to do so, in one scene).  The music adds a lot, especially to the more extreme psycho-drama elements (and they are very extreme).  But still the film is goofy and good-natured, like a Hong Kong film from the same era; the action sequences have that similar low-budget feel.  However, this is very much a western with horses, gun-play and some rocky terrain straight out of Budd Boetticher.  Unlike most westerns, it is 3 1/2 hours long (but suprisingly well-paced).

this is one of my top 5 movies ever . even today it still has the same impact as it did when I first watched it over 20 years ago. all the performances are on point and the music songs subtle, they do not overtake the story but still remain memorable. not your every day bollywood movie. watch this movie and you will not be disappointed.

Ramesh Sippy's Sholay is considered one of the most popular Indian films ever made, and is one of the biggest Indian box-office hits of all time. Sholay is what Star Wars is for most american. The names of the characters that every one knows, and with a handful of actors that has been immortalized, like Amitabh Bachchan's character, Jai, being the Han Solo of Hindi cinema. As a westerner I'm also kind of enchanted  by this film as well.

Sholay is the story about the two small-time thieves and best friends, Veeru (Dharmendra) and Jai (Amitabh Bachchan) who's been hired by the former police chief Thakur (Sanjeev Kumar) to track down the dangerous wanted criminal Gabbar Singh (Amjad Khan) who murdered Thakur's entire family. Thakur want's revenge, and he wants Gabbar alive so that he can deal with him himself.

As a westerner I actually liked Sholay, even though I still have a little problem with the fact that these Bollywood movies are like three hours long. It's actually a western film taking place in a rural indian village, so in this case we can call it a "curry western". It's quite easy to see that this film was influenced by such westerns as "Once Upon a Time in the West" and "The Magnificent Seven". But it's still a strong and emotional revenge tale, never the less.

It's action packed, with a lot of great shootout scenes, with two unstoppable action heroes, Veeru and Jai both kicking it like Butch and Sundance, two against one hundred. And I also love the chemistry between the two friends, with the hot headed Veeru and the cool and calm Jai, who always makes fun of Veeru. I can truly understand why Bachchan is such a beloved actor. And I had nothing against the musical numbers, which I found very entertaining, specially the one with Veeru and Jai on the motorcycle. Overall, I thought that Sholay was quite an amusing and emotional western with great actors. Thumbs up.
The greatest movie of all time and a classic!!!
The most famous hindi movie ever made, and it lives up to it's name!

Sholay is a funny and action filled Bollywood film where Bachchan is easily the standout performer. The movie is quite the journey in itself which at some points feels like it's nearly too long; Sholay still  manages to be a great film.
5/5. Three words: Bollywood's Greatest Film.
Sholay used to be my all time favourite film as a child growing up. I'm only rating this on memory, so I don't know if I still feel the same way about it now.

For better or for worse, 'Sholay' will always hold a special place in my  heart for being the first Bollywood movie I ever saw. It took me a while to watch the films of the largest motion picture conglomerate in the world, but I suppose later is better than never. Interestingly enough, 'Sholay' draws clear influences from Hollywood spaghetti-Westerns, and as far as Bollywood films go it is quite homogeneous, sticking mostly to one genre (action-adventure) rather than mixing multiple ones.

But I bet you're wondering what I thought of the actual movie though. Well, 'Sholay' is the exact representation of what I like to call a 'flawed epic.' The high, intense moments hit especially hard (usually) and the characters are well developed and overcome a long series of trials and tribulations before coming to the ultimate conclusion of the story. 

However, there are a significant number of flaws present in the construction of this film, which is what I mean when I say, 'flawed epic.' Arguably Bollywood's most famous motion picture is far from perfect, and I would also argue should be far from 'classic' status. 'Sholay' suffers from serious pacing issues in the script, especially in its first act. Several scenes early on fail to add anything worthwhile or significant to the plot and were clearly shoved in strictly for comedy's sake --- and were not at all funny in my opinion. With all these errors in pace and flow, one really feels the film's length (3+ hours) at times. Even the film's final battle, between an armless ex-cop and the main villain, comes across as ridiculous.

With all that said, 'Sholay' still succeeds as an exciting action-adventure epic, making the audience care for its main characters (especially the duo of outlaws) and showcasing some pleasant, if obligatory musical numbers. It is probably not worthy of its legendary status, all its flaws considered, but 'Sholay' is going to stay a classic regardless of what most Westerners think.

I see it as the greatest film ever made in our nation . On par with other classics but with new gen sound effects , action and an action packed script combined with one of the best actors of our generation makes it a must watch for all . 
It still inspires film makers and actors alike .
I must watch for all those people who like Amitabh and want to see the first action flick bollywood produced lookin' at Western hollywood movies.
an all time favourite.....one of the best bollywood movies ever

Interesting film from 1975. Some of the action is pretty good. I wasn't keen on a number of things....like most Hindi films it tries to do too much (when you consider that this is the 1970s....and that Hollywood started doing genre mixing only in the last 15 years....you could say it is ahead of it's time). The train part at the beginning was good - then the music and comedy ruined the atmosphere for me. Watch 'Lagaan' or 'Stars On Earth' to see how far Bollywood has come since then.

The first curry western so to speak, in a league of its own.  Leads the genre from the front wit all the masala you can bring to a Bollywood movie.  And for a 1975 production, a little ahead of it's times.  Great screenplay, terrific cinematography and camera work.  R.D. Burman's music is extremely competent though not his best. The best work Ramesh Sippy has ever produced, and considering is earlier/later works, he's got to have had external help.  The train sequence was phenomenal even by today's standards and has Hollywood written all over it. If he had external help, the old fox Sippy ain't telling.

Without a doubt in my top five Bollywood films, perhaps the top 3. Being the kind who rolls his eyes at the love triangles, mushy forbidden romances, and Romeo & Juliet remakes that fill up Bollywood's coffers, I was skeptical when my old man popped in a flick that was older than Reaganomics, but I was hooked within the first five minutes. Discount the sound effects and superhuman feats in the fight scenes--it's an old movie, after all-- and you're left with an action packed film with a couple of badasses and their pistols against an army of dacoits lead by Gabbar Singh. Amjad Khan's fantastic acting and memorable quotes place Gabbar as #2 on my Top Villains from Movies List, behind Scar from the Lion King by inches but miles above #3 (The Emperor/Darth Sidious, for the record). Anyway, if you like Bollywood's acting and setting but are tired of sappy gushy lovey-dovey nonsense, this is the move for you.
This truly deserves the #1 spot on British Film Institute's greatest Indian films of all time.

This movie is the luckiest in the bollywood. I don't know why even today many film experts keep on nagging its name at various place, even though it's concept was taken from Sergio Leone's "Once Upon a Time in West'. Though I don't blame All the Actors, they all were perfect and Amjad Khan was great.

Sometimes families can't agree on what movie to watch. We are always torn between action, musical, western, romantic comedy, and Seven Samurai. Sholay is all of these wrapped up in one movie. Everyone will find something to like, but not everyone will like all three and a half hours of it.

SHOLAY (FLAMES) - 1975 - An absolute classic of Indian cinema.  An Eastern "Western" with Action, Suspense, Comedy, Buddy Pic, Romance, Slapstick...everything and then some.  The locations are spectacular - the action is intense.  Great songs.  Stars Amitabh Bachchan, Dharmendra, Sanjeev Kumar, Amjad Khan, Hema Malini and Jaya Bhaduri (Mrs. Bachchan).  Reportedly, SRK's favorite film.  Good enough for me.
Indian spagetti western.

Sholay

Directed by a Sindhi Ramesh Sippy, this wonderful Hindi film is remake of Seven Samurai, The Magnificent Seven and Once Upon A Time In The West. 

IF YOU HAVEN'T WATCHED SHOLAY, YOU HAVEN'T WATCHED SEVEN SAMURAI, THE MAGNIFICENT SEVEN, and ONCE UPON A TIME IN THE WEST. 

I have watched this movie around 100 times, since I was 8 years old. I love performance of Amjad Khan as Gabbar Singh (in my own list I consider Gabbar Singh to be #1 Best Villain from Indian Cinema). Biggest cast from Indian Cinema, India's legendary actor Amitabh Bachchan as Jay, Dharmendar as Veeru, late Sanjeeve Kumar as Thakur Baldev Singh and late Amjad Khan as notorious outlaw Gabbar Singh. Entire cast involved gives what is to be noted as their careers' only best performances. Memorable dialogues as well as scenes follow in this most-cherished film. 

Thankur a former Police officer, who once captured notorious outlaw Gabbar Singh, was threatened by Gabbar to be punished for capturing him. Gabbar Singh breaks out of prison, and massacres Thakur's family along with a young kid, Thankur in rage goes to take revenge from Gabbar, and gets traped himself. Gabbar cuts off Thankur's hands, as Thakur had gripped Gabbar in his arms while capturing him, saying 'These are not hands but hands made of steel'. Some years later, Thakur recalls two petty thieves, who are close friends named Jai and Veeru played by legendary actors of India 'Amitabh Bachchan and Dharmendra'. Thakur hires them to help him capture Gabbar Singh. First the two decline offer, as Gabbar is most notorious outlaw, but ultimately agree to help the town, which is frequently robbed of grains and flour by outlaw gang of Gabbar every now and then. 

I happen to remember each and every frame of this classic film, directed by Sindhi-Indian director Ramesh Sippy. Under BBC's poll at the near of Millennium, this film was voted #1 Film of Last Century from India.
A real bollywood classic though it's a copy but still I like it.
Classic one of the best movies I've ever seen.
Could be half the length, could star Clint made by Leone. I can genuinely say it's the best curry western I've ever seen.

A slice of Bollywood history, here--or, so I'm told.  It's a timeless tale of good vs. evil and the redemption of bad men through heroism, sacrifice, and love.  I found this Bollywood take unique due, in part,  to the music and dance numbers which would be unthinkable in a similar film produced nearly anywhere else but which fit nicely into the overall story.  (The dance in the bandit's camp is unforgettable.)  Great performances and Bollywood's unique stamp make this familiar tale into a memorable cinematic experience.

while it is clumsy, silly and funny in unintended areas; sholay should be seen for its pure filmi-ness.for, this is bollywood for starters.
1. archetypal character sketches.
2. themes of revenge, justice and love.
3. songs (sung keeping in mind that they can be used on general occasions)
4. choreographed dance numbers.
5. an item number (yes! needs separate mention).
6. comedy (the ones at which my sister chuckled).
7. action sequences (as many as the runtime can hold).
8. death of a protagonist/ lived-happily-ever-after ending.
An absolute epic. Must watch.
Watched this movie over 200 times so far...watching it again today the 201st time. My all time favorite.
A fantastic Bollywood romp spanning all possible genres.
How many films do you know in which chracters with screen presense of less than 3 minutes, are still remembered 35 years after the film release.
how to rate it.its a epic.....watched 100times but still i can spent5 my precious time for this...........copied by thousands of artists,directors and etc etc...........
Greatest movie ever made .every thing is perfect
Retired police inspector hires a couple of thieves to protect a small town from bandits. Classic Bollywood movie intersperses drama with comedy scenes and song and dance numbers.

its an  EPIC

can u believe , every character of this movie is still remmbred today ... 
 even the horse. .... even the coin .
the dialogs are carved inside the minds of every indian . and even till today people earn their living just by narrating its dialogs and enacting its roles . 
Now thts what i call a timeless classic . not even the makers of the movie ever imagined this .

An epic bollywood western that will never be overtaken in fame. It went for over 3hours but was packed with drama and action, romance and even comedy that time flies. The cripple fight at the end was interesting.
I now understand so many Gabbar Singh references, though I dont understand how Abishek Bachchan confused him for being gay in Dostana.
The best Bollywood movie...
I can only say ..CLASSIC movie..had seen more than 100 times..UNFORGETTABLE

Watched this movie for the 'N'th time...
This is undoubtedly the BEST movie that Bollywood has ever produced... Will ever produce !!!
dialog, timing, music, background score, casting....name it & this was the perfect 10 ... like Nadia ....the perfect 10 gymnast from Russia
One of the best movies in Hindi Cinema, you HAVE to watch it.
the every character and all the dialouges of this movie is still popular! oh such a great bollywood movie ever !
only movie where no particular pick of an actor. everyone did good

Undoubtedly, the greatest Indian movie ever made! Everything about this movie is downright classic!

Be it the camerawork, the framing of shots, the editing, the background score, the action sequences, the sound design or the locations... Sholay is an all-time classic cinema!

The story so rooted in Indian heartland, but the treatment had the class and finesse of the best curry western movies. Ramesh Sippy has delivered a movie that will remain unsurpassed by any effort made by any director in Indian filmdom.

This has become a part of collective Indian Consciousness!

"Kitne Aadmi The?"

Absolute classic. I wish I'd had the time to watch it before I wrote about it in my dissertation earlier this year. One of the best bits was an unintentionally funny fight with a guy without arms. All along I wondered, how can he win this?
I can see why people were so taken by Amitabh Bachchan in the 70s as the first anti-hero. One of the only westerns I've ever enjoyed...a 'curry western' apparently. Best bad guy as well. Classic written all over it
you just cannot judge the best performance in this movie everything is just so..............excellent!
